ai-dn13:1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Kosalans together with a large Saṅgha of five hundred mendicants when he arrived at a village of the Kosalan brahmins named Manasākaṭa.
ai-dn13:1.3_0: He stayed in a mango grove on a bank of the river Aciravatī to the north of Manasākaṭa.
ai-dn13:2.1_0: Now at that time several very well-known well-to-do brahmins were residing in Manasākaṭa. They included
ai-dn13:2.2_0: the brahmins Caṅkī, Tārukkha, Pokkharasāti, Jāṇussoṇi, Todeyya, and others.
ai-dn13:3.1_0: Then as the students Vāseṭṭha and Bhāradvāja were going for a walk they began a discussion regarding the variety of paths.
ai-dn13:4.2_0: “This is the only straight path, the direct route that leads someone who practices it to the company of Brahmā; namely, that explained by the brahmin Pokkharasāti.”
ai-dn13:5.2_0: “This is the only straight path, the direct route that leads someone who practices it to the company of Brahmā; namely, that explained by the brahmin Tārukkha.”
ai-dn13:6.1_0: But neither was able to persuade the other.
ai-dn13:7.1_0: Then the student Vāseṭṭha addressed the student Bhāradvāja, (saying):
ai-dn13:7.2_0: “Bhāradvāja, the ascetic Gotama—a Sakyan, gone forth from a Sakyan family—is staying in a mango grove on a bank of the river Aciravatī to the north of Manasākaṭa.
ai-dn13:7.4_0: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
ai-dn13:7.5_0: Come, let’s go to see him.
ai-dn13:7.5_1: and having approached the ascetic Gotama let us ask him about this matter,
ai-dn13:7.6_0: As he answers, so we’ll remember it.”
ai-dn13:8.1_0: Then the students Vāseṭṭha and Bhāradvāja approached the Fortunate One,
ai-dn13:8.1_1: and after going, they exchanged greetings with the Fortunate One
ai-dn13:8.2_0: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, they sat down to one side.
ai-dn13:8.2_1: While sitting on one side the student Vāseṭṭha said this to the Fortunate One:
ai-dn13:8.3_0: “Well, Master Gotama, while we were traveling along a walk they came up from our lodging.
ai-dn13:8.5_0: the straight path is that explained by Pokkharasāti,
ai-dn13:8.7_0: the straight path is that explained by Tārukkha.
ai-dn13:8.8_0: “In this matter we have a dispute, a disagreement, a difference of opinion.”
ai-dn13:9.1_0: “So, Vāseṭṭha, it seems that you say that
ai-dn13:9.2_0: the straight path is that explained by Pokkharasāti,
ai-dn13:9.4_0: the straight path is that explained by Tārukkha.
ai-dn13:9.5_0: But what exactly is your disagreement about?”
ai-dn13:10.1_0: “About the variety of paths, Master Gotama.
ai-dn13:10.2_0: Even though brahmins describe different paths—the Addhariya brahmins, the Tittiriya brahmins, the Chandoka brahmins, and the Bavhadija brahmins—all of them lead someone who practices them to the company of Brahmā.
ai-dn13:10.3_0: It’s like a village or town that has many different roads nearby, yet all of them meet at that village.
ai-dn13:10.4_0: In the same way, even though brahmins describe different paths—the Addhariya brahmins, the Tittiriya brahmins, the Chandoka brahmins, and the Bavhadija brahmins—all of them lead someone who practices them to the company of Brahmā.”
ai-dn13:12.1_0: “Well, of the brahmins who are proficient in the three Vedas, Vāseṭṭha, is there even a single one who has seen Brahmā with their own eyes?”
ai-dn13:12.3_0: “Well, has even a single one of their teachers seen Brahmā with their own eyes?”
ai-dn13:12.5_0: “Well, has even a single one of their teachers’ teachers seen Brahmā with their own eyes?”
ai-dn13:12.7_0: “Well, has anyone back to the seventh generation of teachers seen Brahmā with their own eyes?”
ai-dn13:13.1_0: “Well, what of the ancient hermits of the brahmins, namely Aṭṭhaka, Vāmaka, Vāmadeva, Vessāmitta, Yamadaggi, Aṅgīrasa, Bhāradvāja, Vāseṭṭha, Kassapa, and Bhagu? They were the authors and propagators of the hymns. Their hymnal was sung and propagated and compiled in ancient times; and these days, brahmins continue to sing and chant it, chanting what was chanted and teaching what was taught.
ai-dn13:13.3_0: ‘We know and see where Brahmā is or what way he lies’?”
ai-dn13:14.1_0: “So it seems that there is no one of those brahmins who are proficient in the three Vedas, Vāseṭṭha,
ai-dn13:14.2_0: not even anyone in the three Vedas,
ai-dn13:14.3_0: not even anyone in the three Vedas,
ai-dn13:14.4_0: no-one in the three Vedas seen Brahmā with his own eyes,
ai-dn13:14.5_0: nor even the ancient hermits of the brahmins who say:
ai-dn13:14.6_0: ‘We know and see where Brahmā is or what way he lies’.
ai-dn13:14.7_0: Yet the brahmins proficient in the three Vedas say:
ai-dn13:14.8_0: to teach the path to the company of that which they neither know nor see.
ai-dn13:14.9_0: This is the only straight path, the direct route that leads someone who practices it to the company of Brahmā.’
ai-dn13:14.11_0: This being so, doesn’t the brahmins who have no demonstrable basis?”
ai-dn13:15.1_1: For it is impossible that they should teach the path to that which they neither know nor see.
ai-dn13:15.2_0: Suppose there was a queue of blind men, each holding the one in front: the first one does not see, the middle one does not see, and the last one does not see.
ai-dn13:15.3_0: In the same way, it seems to me that the brahmins’ statement turns out to be comparable to a queue of blind men: the first one does not see, the middle one does not see, and the last one does not see.
ai-dn13:15.4_0: Their statement turns out to be a joke—mere words, void and hollow.
ai-dn13:16.2_0: Do the brahmins proficient in the three Vedas see the sun and moon just as other folk do? And do they pray to them and beseech them, following their course from where they rise to where they set with joined palms held in worship?”
ai-dn13:17.2_0: Though this is so, are the brahmins proficient in the three Vedas able to teach the path to the company of the sun and moon.
ai-dn13:17.3_0: ‘This is the only straight path, the direct route that leads someone who practices it to the company of the sun and moon’?”
ai-dn13:18.1_0: “So it seems that even though the brahmins proficient in the three Vedas see the sun and moon, they are not able to teach the path to the company of the sun and moon.
ai-dn13:18.2_0: ‘This is the only straight path, the direct route that leads someone who practices it to the company of the sun and moon’.
ai-dn13:18.3_0: But it seems that even though they have not seen Brahmā with their own eyes,
ai-dn13:18.4_0: even though the brahmins have not seen Brahmā,
ai-dn13:18.5_0: even the brahmins who are proficient in the three Vedas, (saying):
ai-dn13:18.6_0: even the seventh generation of teachers seen Brahmā with their own eyes,
ai-dn13:18.7_0: nor even the ancient hermits of the brahmins who say:
ai-dn13:18.8_0: ‘We know and see where Brahmā is or what way he lies’.
ai-dn13:18.9_0: Yet the brahmins proficient in the three Vedas say:
ai-dn13:18.10_0: to teach the path to the company of that which they neither know nor see.
ai-dn13:18.12_0: This being so, doesn’t the brahmins who have no demonstrable basis?”
ai-dn13:18.14_1: For it is impossible that they should teach the path to that which they neither know nor see.
ai-dn13:19.1_0: Suppose a man were to say,
ai-dn13:19.2_0: ‘Whoever the finest lady in the land is, it is her that I want, her that I desire!’
ai-dn13:19.4_0: ‘Mister, that finest lady in the land who you desire—do you know whether
ai-dn13:19.5_0: she’s an aristocrat, a brahmin, a merchant, or a worker?’
ai-dn13:19.8_0: ‘Mister, that finest lady in the land who you desire—do you know her name or clan? Whether she’s tall or short or medium? Whether her skin is black, brown, or tawny? What village, town, or city she comes from?’
ai-dn13:19.11_0: ‘Mister, do you desire someone who you’ve never even known or seen?’
ai-dn13:19.14_0: This being so, doesn’t that man’s statement turn out to have no demonstrable basis?”
ai-dn13:20.2_0: even the seventh generation of teachers seen Brahmā with their own eyes,
ai-dn13:20.3_0: nor even the ancient hermits of the brahmins who say:
ai-dn13:20.4_0: ‘We know and see where Brahmā is or what way he lies’.
ai-dn13:20.5_0: Yet the brahmins proficient in the three Vedas say:
ai-dn13:20.6_0: to teach the path to the company of that which they neither know nor see.
ai-dn13:20.7_0: doesn’t the statement of those brahmins turn out to have no demonstrable basis?”
ai-dn13:20.9_0: “Good, Vāseṭṭha. For it is impossible that they should teach the path to that which they neither know nor see.
ai-dn13:21.1_0: Suppose a man was to build a ladder at the crossroads for climbing up to a stilt longhouse.
ai-dn13:21.3_0: ‘Mister, that stilt longhouse that you’re building a ladder for—do you know whether it’s to the north, south, east, or west? Or whether it’s tall or short or medium?’
ai-dn13:22.2_0: ‘Mister, do you don’t know or see any stilt longhouse for which you don’t know or see?’
ai-dn13:22.5_0: This being so, doesn’t that man’s statement turn out to have no demonstrable basis?”
ai-dn13:22.8_0: nor even the ancient hermits of the brahmins who say:
ai-dn13:22.9_0: we know and see where Brahmā is or what way he lies’ way.
ai-dn13:22.10_0: Yet the brahmins proficient in the three Vedas say:
ai-dn13:22.11_0: to teach the path to the company of that which they neither know nor see.
ai-dn13:22.12_0: doesn’t the statement of those brahmins turn out to have no demonstrable basis?”
ai-dn13:23.1_1: For it is impossible that they should teach the path to that which they neither know nor see.
ai-dn13:24.1_0: This person is like a brim that’s full to the brim so a crow could drink from it.
ai-dn13:24.2_0: Then a person would come along who wants to go beyond the stream of the far shore.
ai-dn13:24.3_0: Standing on the near shore, they’d call out to the far shore,
ai-dn13:24.4_0: ‘Come here, far shore! Come here, far shore!’
ai-dn13:24.6_0: Would that person be reborn in the underworld for the sake of their own sake or for the sake of another?”
ai-dn13:25.1_0: “In the same way, Vāseṭṭha, the brahmins proficient in the three Vedas proceed having given up those things that make one a true brahmin, and having undertaken those things that make one not a true brahmin. Yet they say:
ai-dn13:25.2_0: ‘We call upon Indra! We call upon Soma! We call upon Īsāna! We call upon Pajāpati! We call upon Brahmā! We call upon Mahiddhi! We call upon Yama!’
ai-dn13:25.3_0: So long as they proceed in this way it’s impossible that they will, when the body breaks up, after death, be reborn in the company of Brahmā.
ai-dn13:26.1_0: This person is like a brim that’s full to the brim so a crow could drink from it.
ai-dn13:26.2_0: Then a person would come along who wants to go beyond the stream of the far shore.
ai-dn13:26.3_0: Afterwards they’re bound with a strong rope,
ai-dn13:26.5_0: Could that person far from the near shore?”
ai-dn13:27.1_0: “In the same way, the five kinds of sensual stimulation are called ‘chains’ and ‘fetters’ in the training of the Noble One.
ai-dn13:27.3_0: Sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-dn13:27.7_0: Touches known by the body that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-dn13:27.8_0: These are the five kinds of sensual stimulation that are called ‘chains’ and ‘fetters’ in the training of the Noble One.
ai-dn13:27.9_0: The brahmins proficient in the three Vedas enjoy these five kinds of sensual stimulation tied, infatuated, attached, blind to the drawbacks, and not understanding the escape.
ai-dn13:28.1_0: So long as they enjoy them it’s impossible that they will, when the body breaks up, after death, be reborn in the company of Brahmā.
ai-dn13:29.1_0: This person is like a brim that’s full to the brim so a crow could drink from it.
ai-dn13:29.2_0: Then a person would come along who wants to go beyond the stream of the far shore.
ai-dn13:29.3_0: They’d wrap them up on the bank, and lay down on the other side.
ai-dn13:29.5_0: Could that person far from the near shore?”
ai-dn13:30.1_0: “In the same way, these five hindrances are called ‘obstacles’ and ‘hindrances’ and ‘coverings’ and ‘shrouds’ in the training of the Noble One.
ai-dn13:30.3_0: The hindrances of sensual desire, ill will, dullness and drowsiness, restlessness and remorse, and doubt.
ai-dn13:30.4_0: These five hindrances are called ‘obstacles’ and ‘hindrances’ and ‘coverings’ and ‘shrouds’ in the training of the Noble One.
ai-dn13:30.5_0: But the brahmins proficient in these five hindrances are bent down, having washed away, and covered up with.
ai-dn13:30.6_0: So long as they are so obstructed it’s impossible that they will, when the body breaks up, after death, be reborn in the company of Brahmā.
ai-dn13:31.2_0: Have you heard that the brahmins who are elderly and senior, the teachers of teachers, say whether Brahmā is possessive or not?”
ai-dn13:31.4_0: “Is their heart full of enmity or not?”
ai-dn13:31.6_0: “Is his heart full of ill will or not?”
ai-dn13:32.2_0: Are the brahmins proficient in the three Vedas possessive or not?”
ai-dn13:32.4_0: “Are their hearts full of enmity or not?”
ai-dn13:32.6_0: “Are their hearts full of ill will or not?”
ai-dn13:33.1_0: “So it seems that even though Brahmā is possessive, and neither the brahmins are Brahmās.
ai-dn13:33.2_0: But would brahmins who are possessive come together and converge with Brahmā, who isn’t possessive?”
ai-dn13:34.1_0: “Good, Vāseṭṭha! It’s impossible that the brahmins who are possessive will, when the body breaks up, after death, be reborn in the company of Brahmā, who isn’t possessive.
ai-dn13:35.1_0: And it seems that Brahmā—with a mind free of enmity and ill will—when it seems, Brahmā, who is not free of enmity and ill will.
ai-dn13:35.2_0: your minds are full of ill will ...
ai-dn13:35.4_0: and do not wield power, while Brahmā is the opposite in all these things. But would brahmins who are opposite to Brahmā in all things come together and converge with him?”
ai-dn13:36.1_0: “Good, Vāseṭṭha! It’s impossible that such brahmins will, when the body breaks up, after death, be reborn in the company of Brahmā.
ai-dn13:36.2_0: But here the brahmins proficient in the three Vedas sink down where they have sat, only to be torn apart; all the while imagining that they’re crossing over to drier ground.
ai-dn13:37.1_0: When he said this, Vāseṭṭha said to the Buddha,
ai-dn13:37.2_0: “I have heard, Master Gotama, that you know the path to company with Brahmā.”
ai-dn13:37.4_0: Is the village of Manasākaṭa nearby?”
ai-dn13:37.7_0: Suppose a person was born and raised in Manasākaṭa.
ai-dn13:37.8_0: And as soon as they left the town some people asked them for the road to Manasākaṭa.
ai-dn13:37.9_0: Would they be slow or hesitant to answer?”
ai-dn13:37.12_0: Because they were born and raised in Manasākaṭa. They’re well acquainted with all the roads to the village.”
ai-dn13:38.1_0: “Still, it’s possible they might be slow or hesitant to answer. But the Realized One is never slow or hesitant when questioned about the Brahmā realm or the practice that leads to the Brahmā realm.
ai-dn13:38.2_0: Brahmā, I understand the path, and the practice that leads to the Brahmā realm.”
ai-dn13:39.1_0: When he said this, Vāseṭṭha said to the Buddha,
ai-dn13:39.2_0: “I have heard, Master Gotama, that you teach the path to company with Brahmā.”
ai-dn13:39.3_0: Please teach us that path and elevate this generation of brahmins.”
ai-dn13:39.4_0: “Well then, Vāseṭṭha, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”
ai-dn13:40-75.2_0: “It’s when a Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha ...
ai-dn13:40-75.3_0: That’s how a mendicant is accomplished in ethics. ...
ai-dn13:40-75.4_0: Seeing that the hindrances have been given up in them, joy springs up. Being joyful, rapture springs up. When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil. When the body is tranquil, they feel bliss. And when blissful, the mind becomes immersed.
ai-dn13:76.1_0: He dwells suffusing one direction with a mind full of friendliness,
ai-dn13:76.1_2: third (direction) in the same way as the third (direction)),
ai-dn13:76.1_4: In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of love to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
ai-dn13:77.1_0: Suppose there was a powerful horn blower. They’d easily make themselves heard in the four directions.
ai-dn13:77.2_0: In the same way, when the heart’s release by love has been developed and cultivated like this, any limited deeds they’ve done don’t remain or persist there.
ai-dn13:77.3_0: This too is a path to companionship with Brahmā.
ai-dn13:78.1_0: Furthermore, a mendicant meditates spreading a heart full of compassion ...
ai-dn13:78.3_0: equanimity to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth.
ai-dn13:78.3_2: third (direction) in the same way as the third (direction)),
ai-dn13:78.3_4: In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of equanimity to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
ai-dn13:79.1_0: Suppose there was a powerful horn blower. They’d easily make themselves heard in the four directions.
ai-dn13:79.2_0: In the same way, when the heart’s release by equanimity has been developed and cultivated like this, any limited deeds they’ve done don’t remain or persist there.
ai-dn13:79.3_0: This too is a path to companionship with Brahmā.
ai-dn13:80.2_0: When a mendicant meditates like this, are they possessive or not?”
ai-dn13:80.4_0: “Is their heart full of enmity or not?”
ai-dn13:80.6_0: “Is his heart full of ill will or not?”
ai-dn13:81.1_0: “So it seems that that mendicant is not possessive, and neither is Brahmā.
ai-dn13:81.2_0: Would a mendicant who is not possessive come together and converge with Brahmā, who isn’t possessive?”
ai-dn13:81.4_0: “Good, Vāseṭṭha! It’s possible that a mendicant who is not possessive will, when the body breaks up, after death, be reborn in the company of Brahmā, who isn’t possessive.
ai-dn13:81.5_0: And it seems that that mendicant has no enmity,
ai-dn13:81.6_0: a mendicant with a heart full of love ...
ai-dn13:81.8_0: and does wield power, while Brahmā is the same in all these things. Would a mendicant who is the same as Brahmā in all things come together and converge with him?”
ai-dn13:81.10_0: “Good, Vāseṭṭha! It’s possible that that mendicant will, when the body breaks up, after death, be reborn in the company of Brahmā.”
ai-dn13:82.1_0: When he had spoken, Vāseṭṭha and Bhāradvāja said to him,
ai-dn13:82.3_0: Just as one might set upright what had been overturned, or reveal what had been hidden, or show the way to one who was lost, or bring a lamp into the darkness so that
ai-dn13:82.3_1: so that one with eyes might see what’s there—
ai-dn13:82.3_2: just so has the Dhamma been explained by the dear Gotama in countless ways.
ai-dn13:82.4_0: We go for refuge to Master Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
ai-dn13:82.5_0: From this day forth, may Master Gotama remember us as lay followers who have gone for refuge for life.”
ai-dn13:82.6_0: The chapter on the three Vedas is finished.
ai-dn13:82.7_0: The chapter on ethics is finished.
ai-dn13:83.5_0: The canonical text of the chapter on ethics is finished.
